item.title: 5-1 Designing a Web API
item.description:
In an Ajax web app, the application server implements a Web API that provides service to the front-end JavaScript code.

A Web API is a defined set of HTTP request messages along with a definition of the structure of response messages, usually expressed in an XML or JSON format (from Wikipedia).

RPC-style Web API

A common design style of Web API is RPC-style (Remote Procedure Call). A RPC-style Web API consists of one URL for each function or operation. These URLs represent an action and are usually named with a verb. The following table shows the five endpoints in the Web API of our sample web app. They implement four common operations on data known as CRUD (Create, Retrieve, Update an Delete).

method URL function
GET /getTodo List all tasks in json format
GET /searchTodo Search tasks that are due before the given date.
POST /addTodo Add a task. Message body contains properties of the new task, except id.
POST /updateTodo Update a task. Message body contains id of the updated todo and properties with new value
POST /deleteTodo Delete the task with id included in message body

An endpoint uses GET if the operation is read-only. If the operation may causes some action or side-effect on the server side, the endpoint must use POST.

Read-only operations

A Web API may return result in either key-value pairs (www-url-encoded) or JSON. Key-value pairs are only suitable for simple values. JSON is more flexible in representing data structure.

Sample request message to retrieve tasks:

GET /getTodo HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com

Below is a sample response message returned by the Web API. The JSON payload has Content-type: applicatin/json. The JSON data format is mostly the same as JavaScript object syntax. But it can only contain simple values (namely numbers, strings and boolean) and all property names must be quoted.

HTTP/1.1 200 Ok
Content-type: application/json
Content-length: 234

{
  "count": 2,
  "task": [     
    { "id": 1, "due": "2016-11-11", "what": "Test",
      "category": "study", "done": 0 },
    { "id": 2, "due": "2016-12-13", "what": "Final exam",
      "category": "study", "done": 0 }
  ]
}

A client may pass simple parameters to the Web API using query. This is similar to web search form submission. Below is a request for the endpoint GET /searchTodo to search tasks that are due before a given date. Note that HTTP GET requests cannot contain a body, so any data must be passed in the URL.

GET /searchTodo?before=2016-12-01 HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com

Some designers use HTTP status codes like 400 and 500 to report runtime error. Other designers choose to use the JSON payload to report error. What is important is that you should be consistent.

HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request
Content-type: text/plain
Content-length: 26

Date format error in input

HTTP/1.1 500 Internal Server Error
Content-type: application/json
Content-length: 63

{ "errorCode": 1001, "message": "Database connection problem" }

HTTP/1.1 200 Ok
Content-type: application/json
Content-length: 63

{ "errorCode": 1001, "message": "Database connection problem" }

Update operations

The endpoints of any update operations must use POST. It informs that any web proxy servers between the client and the Web API should not cache response of the operations. In update operations, there are usually some input parameters. You can pass simple parameters as key-value pairs (i.e. www-form-urlencoded) in the request message body. Key-value pairs are usually easier to work with in client-side programming (e.g. using jQuery).

Below is a sample request for adding a task in the Web API.

POST /addTodo HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
Content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-length: 53

due=2017-01-06&what=Makeup+exam&category=study&done=0

For more complicated data, use JSON data format.

POST /addTodo HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
Content-type: application/json
Content-length: 80

{ "due": "2017-01-06", "what": "Makeup exam",
  "category": "study", "done": 0 }

A successful response from an update operation may not contain any payload. You can use HTTP status code 204 in this case.

HTTP/1.1 204 No content

On the other hand, if the Web API provides some info about the update operation, include the data as urlencoded or JSON payload.

HTTP/1.1 200 Ok
Content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-length: 4

id=21

We finish this section with sample HTTP request and response messages for the remaining two endpoints of the Web API, namely POST /updateTodo and POST /deleteTodo.

In the updateTodo operation, the client must specify the id of the task to change, and then list the properties and their new values.

POST /updateTodo HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
Content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-length: 53

id=21&what=Makeup+exam+COMP312

For the delete operation, the client must specify the id of the task to delete. The input parameter is very simple. There are two common designs for this case.

POST /deleteTodo HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
Content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-length: 4

id=3

or

POST /deleteTodo?id=3 HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com

We’ll use the first design in our sample app for consistency. I.e. we also pass input parameters to POST endpoints in request message body.

Exercise

  1. Write sample response messages for the POST /updateTodo endpoint for successful update, and unsuccessful update because the record with the given id does not exist.

  2. Design a new endpoint GET /getTodoWithId, to retrieve a task with a given id. Write sample response messages for successful and unsuccessful retrieval.

  3. Design a new endpoint for the Web API for the operation of marking a task as done (i.e. set the done property to 1 in the server database.) Write sample response messages for successful and unsuccessful retrieval. In your answer, describe what input parameters are required.

item.title: 4-1 Node.js primer
item.description:
This lab goes through the basics of the Node.js platform.

Quick start

Node.js (https://nodejs.org) is a platform built on Chrome’s JavaScript runtime V8 for easily building fast, scalable network applications. Node.js supports the same basic JavaScript programming language as web browsers. As the first example, let’s run the following program p101.js in both browser and Node. (Follow instruction to install Node.)

// p101.js

// return the largest number in an array
// assume at least 1 entry, and all entries are numbers
function largest (A) {
  var big=A[0];
  for (var i=1; i<A.length; i++) {
    if (big<A[i]) big=A[i];
  }
  return big;
}

var N = [ 3, 7, 6, 8, 2, 5 ];

console.log('The largest is %d', largest(N));

The JavaScript engine provides some common features in both Node and browsers:

  • JavaScript language features: control flow, variables, data structure, defining class, functions, regular expression, etc
  • Some global objects and functions:
    • console.log()
    • timers: setInterval(), setTimeout()
    • Date class: var now = new Date()
    • JSON processing: JSON.parse(), JSON.stringify()

But Node misses some features specific to the browser platform, e.g.

  • document tree (i.e. DOM tree)
    • a Node program generally does not involve an HTML document
    • no interface and mouse or keyboard events
    • usually we don’t use jQuery’s $( ) in Node
  • AJAX
    • but there are other objects for network operations
  • and other APIs in the Web API

Event loop in Node

Similar to JavaScript runtime in browser, Node includes an event loop that handles events. The event loop continues until all events are handled and there are no future events. Some common cases that trigger events are:

  • timer: when time is up, call a functions
  • file I/O, network I/O, etc: When some data is ready to read, or some I/O operations finish, the Node runtime triggers an event and call an event handler
  • some objects can generate events
  • system events, e.g. Ctrl-C interrupt

Trace the execution of the following program.

// p102.js

var N = 10; // countdown from 10
var timer;  // id of the timer

function tick() {
  if (N<=0) {
    console.log("Time's up!");
    clearInterval(timer);
  } else {
    console.log(N); N--;
  }
}

// this starts the timer
timer = setInterval(tick, 1000);

// event loop runs here ...

At any time, Node runs at most 1 event handler. If there are no pending events, the event loop blocks and waits for any future events. If Node determines that there are no more future events, it quits.

Modules

An important feature of Node is modules, which allows you to import new functionalities to the Node platform. The Node platform comes with some built-in modules (which are installed together with Node). See the online reference for a list of the built-in modules.

To use a module, import it with require(). This function returns an object that represents the module in your program. You can assign this to a variable of any convenient name.

(You can use the REPL tool Mancy for experiment in this part.)

var url = require('url');
var a = url.parse('http://example.com/path/file.js?a=2#hash1');

(You can also download modules from the Web and install in the Node platform. We’ll come to that later in this chapter.)

The following example demonstrates how to use another built-in module os and the built-in class Date to monitor the amount of free memory. (online reference)

// p103.js
// show amount of free memory every second
var os = require('os');

function tick() {
  var now = new Date();
  var time = now.toTimeString().substring(0,8);
  var fm = os.freemem() / 1024;
  console.log(`${time} - ${fm}k`);
}

console.log('Start monitoring free memory. Ctrl-C to quit.')
setInterval(tick, 1000);

Evented I/O

Node.js has only 1 thread to run JavaScript code. If this thread blocks to wait for I/O completion, the whole Node process is blocked and cannot process other events. Consider the following example.

var fs = require('fs');
// this function blocks.
// if other event fires while Node is waiting
// for the file read operation to finish,
// the event loop CANNOT run the event handlers.
var data = fs.readFileSync('intro.txt', 'utf8' );
console.log('File content: ', data);

fs.readFileSync() and fs.writeFileSync() are two of the few synchronous I/O functions in Node. They blocks the single thread of Node while waiting for the input / output to finish.

In other platforms like Java, one usually needs to create multiple threads to handle several I/O operations at the same time (e.g. a web server handling multiple clients). Node uses evented I/O to allow more than one I/O at the same time. At the time you start an I/O operation, you also need to provide a callback function. After I/O is done, the event loop will call the callback function and pass either an error, or the result of the I/O.

var fs = require('fs');

fs.readFile('intro.txt', 'utf8', (err, data)=>{
  // if there is error, handle it, or throw it to quit
  if (err) throw err;
  // no error, the I/O result is 'data'
  console.log('File content: ', data);
} );

// at this point, file read is still in progress
// ...

// event loop waits for I/O to finish

In the above example, the third parameter is the callback function. fs.readFile returns immediately without blocking. However, the I/O result is not available yet.

Here is a summary of simple asynchronous file I/O operations in the module fs. Refer to the online reference of module fs for detail.

  • fs.readFile(filename, options, callback) - read content from the file
  • fs.writeFile(filename, content, options, callback) - write the given content to the file
  • fs.appendFile(filename, content, options, callback) - append the given content to the end of the file

In Node, many asynchronous I/O operations have a callback parameter. These operations generate an once-off event when the I/O completes (with data or error). Usually, the first parameter of the callback is an error object. Since the callback is run by the event loop (and not by any other functions), throwing an error inside the callback will quit the process.

Sequential I/O operations

Consider the following longer example. We’d like to replace the word ‘MPI’ by ‘IPM’ in the input file ‘intro.txt’. To ensure that writeFile is done after readFile returns data, call writeFile in the callback for readFile.

// p105.js
// asynchronous version of read file, process, and write file
var fs = require('fs');

fs.readFile('intro.txt', 'utf8', (err, data)=>{
  if (err) throw err;
  // at this moment, file read is done
  var newdata = data.replace(/MPI/g, 'IPM');
  // we can start file write now
  fs.writeFile('change.txt', newdata, 'utf8', (err)=>{
    if (err) throw err;
  });
});

In general, doing some I/O operations in sequence would involve nesting callback functions. The result is sometimes known as callback hell in the Node community. You can sometimes reduce callback nesting by moving the callback to top level functions. The following rewrite of the above program demonstrates this.

// p105.js rewrite: move callback to top level functions
var fs = require('fs');

function writeDone (err) {
  if (err) throw err;
}

function readDone (err, data) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var newdata = data.replace(/MPI/g, 'IPM');
  fs.writeFile('change.txt', newdata, 'utf8', writeDone);
}

fs.readFile('intro.txt', 'utf8', readDone);

Exercises

  1. Write a program to combine two text file ‘in1.txt’ and ‘in2.txt’ to an output text file ‘out.txt’. Use asynchronous I/O functions fs.readFile() and fs.writeFile(). (solution: p106.js)

  2. Write a program to monitor the amount of available memory to a log file ‘freemem.txt’. Hints: use fs.appendFile() to append log message to the txt file.

item.title: 3-1 Quick start
item.description:
document tree and JavaScript libraries

When a web browser loads an HTML page from a web server, it converts the HTML code into a tree formed data structure known as document tree. All user interactions in the client-side of a web app are done through this DOM tree.

The Document Object Model standard (online ref) defines a programming interface to access the document tree. Each HTML element is represented by a node in the tree. DOM defines the properties, methods and events for these nodes, and the nodes are accessible to JavaScript as objects. In summary, DOM defines how JavaScript code can access and manipulate nodes in a document tree.

Demo === demo text ===:

  • document tree in JavaScript: document
  • search a node, and node as an object (with properties and methods): var a = document.getElementById('mesg')
  • change a property of the node object: a.innerText = 'new content'

However, using DOM directly takes a lot of efforts. (DOM is complex and verbose.) Developers usually prefer some higher level JavaScript library to do client-side programming (e.g. Facebook React, Google AngularJS) In this chapter, we’ll use a popular library called jQuery.

A short description of the jQuery library from the official site:

jQuery is a fast, small, and feature-rich JavaScript library. It makes things like HTML document traversal and manipulation, event handling, animation, and Ajax much simpler with an easy-to-use API that works across a multitude of browsers.

First example

This example shows several features in client-side web app programming. In this app, the user enters two numbers in text input boxes, presses a button to calculate the sum, and displays the result inside the web page.

<!doctype html>
<html>
<head>
  <title>First example</title>
</head>
<body>
  <p>This example adds two numbers.</p>
  <!-- define user interface with HTML -->
  <p>a: <input type="text" id="numA" /></p>
  <p>b: <input type="text" id="numB" /></p>
  <p><button type='button' id="btnAdd">Calculate!</button></p>
  <p>a+b = <span id="ans"></span></p>
  <!-- load the jQuery library -->
  <script src="jquery.js"></script>
  <script>
    // register event handler for 'click' on the button
    $('#btnAdd').on('click', e => {
      // read value in input boxes and convert to number
      var a = $('#numA').val();
      a = parseInt(a);
      var b = $('#numB').val();
      b = parseInt(b);
      // calculate sum and show answer in the <span> element
      $('#ans').html(a+b);
    });
  </script>
</body>
</html>

As the example shows, there are several common steps in the client-side web app:

  • select elements in DOM tree. jQuery provides the function $(CSS selector) to select elements with CSS selectors.
  • read content of elements. The above example uses the method $().val() to read input in text box.
  • change content of elements. The example uses the method $().html() to set the element content
  • handle events. You can register event handlers for certain event with the method .on(event, callback)

A note on loading JavaScript code

In most of our examples, we put JavaScript code near the end of the HTML document. We typically put them just before the end tag </body>. This makes sure that the DOM tree is complete when the JavaScript code runs.

We use the following HTML code to load jQuery library from our local web site (same location as the HTML code). In a more complicated web app, it is better to put JavaScript libraries in their own folder. You can also load the jQuery library from one of the public CDN. Refer to these pages for detail: jQuery CDN, Google Hosted Library and cdnjs.

<script src="jquery.js"></script>

After loading the jQuery library, we can load our own code. You can save the code in a separate js file and load with a syntax similar to above. Alternatively, you can embed the code within a <script> element, as in our example.

We embed JavaScript code in many of our example for sake of simplicity. However, in production code, it is generally recommended to remove JavaScript code from HTML file and move them to external JavaScript file.

item.title: 2-1 Basic data types and control
item.description:
This lab goes through the basic data types (Number and String) and control structures of the JavaScript programming language.

Number

Two basic data types in JavaScript are Number and String. There are no separate types for integers and doubles. (You define a variable x with var x. In ES6, you can also declare variables with let x and constants with const x.)

var a = 1;
var b = 2e3;  /* 2 * (10*10*10) */
var c;  /* c is undefined */
c = a * 1.5 + b;
console.log(c);

In addition to the basic arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /, %) (ref), the Math built-in object (ref) provides some useful functions (e.g. Math.random(), Math.floor(), Math.ceil(), Math.round(), Math.pow(), Math.sqrt() and trigonometric functions.)

(Btw, the trailing semicolons of statements may be omitted if there is only 1 statement on a line.)

var r = 10
var area = Math.PI * r * r
// same as Math.PI * Math.pow(r,2)

// a number from 1,2,3,4,5 and 6
// Math.random() returns a number between 0 and 1
var dice = Math.floor(Math.random()*6)+1

var x = Math.sin(Math.PI/2)  // 1
var y = Math.sqrt(-1) // NaN

String

Strings can be delimited with single quote or double quote. Join two strings with +. Use the property .length to check number of characters in a string.

var user = "peterchan";
var domain = 'ymail.com';
var addr = user + "@" + domain;
var n = "seven".length;  // 5

String literals use backslash \ to escape character, e.g. \", \', \\ and \n.

// no need to escape, but if you may
var s1 = 'A string with "double quoted text".'
// escape the backlash character
var s2 = 'c:\\inetpub\\index.html';

String literals can also use methods defined in the String class (ref). Examples:

var text = 'Mississippi';
var p = text.indexOf('ss'); // location of 'ss'
var mesg = "All the best";
p = mesg.slice(0,3); // 'All'
p = mesg.slice(4); // 'the best'
p = mesg.slice(-4); // 'best'
p = mesg.slice(-4,-2); // 'be'

var A = "202.175.3.3".split('.');
// an array ['202', '175', '3', '3']

Conversion

User input are usually returned as string. Before calculation, use parseInt() or parseFloat() to convert the string into an integer / floating point number.

var s = "3.14";
// unexpected result of string concatenation
console.log(s+1);
var pi = parseFloat(s);
console.log(pi+1);

There are various methods to change a number into a string.

var n = 12;
var s1 = n.toString();  // "12"
var s2 = '' + n; // automatic conversion in string concatenation

A new features in ES6 is template string. Template strings support interpolation. They evaluate JavaScript expressions embedded in ${} and insert the result into the string. Notice the back ticks used to delimit a template string.

var user = "Peter";
var age = 18;
var s = `${user}'s age is ${age}`;
console.log(s);

A longer example to illustrate number-string conversion.

var s = window.prompt('Enter radius of the circle');
var r = parseFloat(s);
console.log(`Area = ${Math.PI * r * r}`);

Comparison

You can compare numbers and strings using the operators <, <=, >, >=, == and !=. Comparison results are either true or false, which are the only two values in boolean data type.

"apple" == "Apple" // false
"apple" < 'banana' // true

The first four operators may convert the data if they are of different data type. It is especially confusing if you compare numbers with strings. JavaScript converts strings into numbers before comparison. In general, it is better to do the conversion by yourself.

"1" == 1.0 // true
3 == '3.0' // true
'3' == '3.0' // false!

Some authors recommend the usage of === instead of == in comparison. The operator === does not convert values before comparison. Similarly, !== checks whether two values are not equal without automatic type conversion.

Similar to Java, you can use && and || to combine comparison tests.

Control structure

The control structure if, for and while are similar to those in Java. Please read the online reference of if…else, for, while and switch for detail.

An example of if to solve quadratic equations 

var a = 1, b = -3, c = 2;  // roots are 1 and 2
// var a = 1, b = 0, c = 1;  // roots are i and -i

var det = b * b - 4 * a * c;
var root1, root2;
if (det>=0) {
  // these two are Number
  root1 = (-b - Math.sqrt(det)) / (2*a);
  root2 = (-b + Math.sqrt(det)) / (2*a);
} else {
  // these two are String.. sorry, no complex number support
  root1 = `${-b/2/a} - ${Math.sqrt(-det)/2/a}i`;
  root2 = `${-b/2/a} + ${Math.sqrt(-det)/2/a}i`;
}
console.log(`${a} x^2 + ${b} x + ${c} = 0`);
console.log(`The roots are ${root1} and ${root2}`);

Examples on loops.

// calculate 1+2+3+...+10;
var sum = 0;
for (var k=1; k<=10; k++) {
  sum += k;
}
console.log(`The sum of 1+2+...+10 = ${sum}.`);

// calculate 1*1+2*2+...+n*n, where n*n<100;
var i = 1; var sum = 0;
while (i*i<100) {
  sum += i*i;
  i++;
}
console.log(`The sum of squares < 100 is ${sum}.`)

A note on loose typing

You might have noticed that when you define a variable with var x, you don’t need to specify a data type. A JavaScript variable is not tied to a specific data type in declaration, and can hold values of different data types.

var x = 10;
x++;  // x is a Number
x = x.toString(2);  // binary representation
console.log(x); // x is now a String

Exercise

  1. Write a program to calculate the sum of even positive numbers up to 30. (The answer should be 240)

  2. The following program asks the user a number n, and print a n by n squares to console.

    var s = window.prompt('Enter size of the square');
/* convert the input string into a number */
var n = parseInt(s);
/* build a line with n stars */
var line = '';
for (var i=0; i<n; i++) { line = line + '* '; }
/* build a square with n lines */
var sqr = '';
for (i=0; i<n; i++) { sqr = sqr + line + '\n';}
console.log(sqr);

    Modify the program to print an empty square.

    * * * * *
*       *
*       *
*       *
* * * * *

item.title: 5-2 Implmenting a Web API
item.description:
In this lab, we’ll discuss implementation of the Web API in last section using Express framework.

Endpoints with GET method

This section implements two endpoints of a Web API. Both are read-only and use GET method. They return the result in JSON data format.

method URL function
GET /getTodo List all tasks
GET /searchTodo Search tasks that are due before the given date.

Typically, we define a route in an Express app to implement an endpoint in a Web API. Below is a simple implementation of retrieval of all tasks from a database. You can easily test this route by loading an URL like http://localhost:3000/getTodo in a browser.

app.get('/getTodo', (req, res) => {
  db.all("SELECT * FROM task ORDER BY due DESC", function(err, rows) {
    if (err) {
      // return HTTP status code 500 to report internal server error
      res.status(500).send(err);
    } else {
      // sending JavaScript object creates a JSON response
      res.send({ count: rows.length, task: rows });
    }
  });
});

A web API endpoint with GET method may take input parameters in query part of the URL (e.g. /searchTodo?before=2016-10-27) These parameters are available in req.query in an Express route. Below is an example of another endpoint for searching tasks due before a given date. This example also demonstrates sanity check of input parameters and error reporting. When the app server receives a request for /searchTodo?before=2016-10-27, it sets the query object req.query = { before: '2016-10-27' }.

app.get('/searchTodo', (req, res) => {
  // parameter sanity check
  var before = req.query.before;
  if (/^\d\d\d\d-\d\d-\d\d$/.test(before)===false) {
    // error in input parameters
    res.status(400).end();
    return;
  }
  db.all("SELECT * FROM task WHERE due <= ? ORDER BY due DESC",
    [ before ],
    function(err, rows) {
      if (err) {
        // internal server error
        res.status(500).send(err);
      } else {
        // sending JavaScript object creates a JSON response
        res.send({ count: rows.length, task: rows });
      }
    }
  );
});

Endpoints with POST method

This section discusses implementation of three endpoints (listed below) that use POST method. They take input parameters in urlencoded format which are enclosed in the message body of the requests.

method URL function
POST /addTodo Add a task. Message body contains properties of the new task, except id.
POST /updateTodo Update a task. Message body contains id of the updated todo and properties with new value
POST /deleteTodo Delete the task with id included in message body

The route below is a simple implementation of adding a new task to the database. The route obtains the input parameters from req.body instead of req.query because the input parameters are passed in the request message body. After error checking of input parameters, the code executes INSERT SQL statement to add a task to the database. It returns HTTP status code 204 if INSERT is successful. Otherwise, it returns status code 500.

app.post('/addTodo', (req, res) => {
  // obtain the input parameters from the message body
  var due = req.body.due;
  var what = req.body.what;
  var category = req.body.category;
  var done = req.body.done;
  if (done==undefined) done = 0;  // default value

  // sanity check of input parameters
  if (due===undefined || what===undefined || category===undefined) {
    res.status(400).send('Cannot add new. '+'content '+JSON.stringify(req.body));
    // console.log(req.body);
    return;
  }

  db.run("INSERT INTO task (due, what, category, done) VALUES (?,?,?,?)",
    [due, what, category, done],
    function(err) {
      if (err) {
        res.status(500).send(err);
      } else {
        res.status(204).end();
      }
  });

});

Refer to the source code of app.js in the Ajax web app for the implementation of the endpoints POST /updateTodo and POST /deleteTodo.

Exercise

Implement the endpoint for the operation of marking a task as done (the last question in the previous section).

item.title: 4-2 NPM modules
item.description:
In this lab, we will

  • install module with npm install
  • demonstrate how send HTTP requests using the request modules.
  • cover the concept of a Node app and dependency management in package.json

Installing Modules

Node.js has a built-in module called http and https for making HTTP clients and servers. They are efficient implementation of the HTTP protocol. However, the modules are low-level and not convenient to use. Therefore, the Node community has developed several modules for writing HTTP clients and servers. These modules are published in https://www.npmjs.com/. A popular choice for HTTP clients is the request module. (online reference).

Using Request to GET an URL

The following example fetches the current weather report from http://rss.smg.gov.mo/e_ActualWeather_rss.xml.

// p301.js
var request = require('request');

var url = 'http://rss.smg.gov.mo/e_ActualWeather_rss.xml';
request.get(url, (err, res, body) => {
  console.log('STATUS: ' + res.statusCode);
  console.log('HEADERS: ');
  console.dir(res.headers);
  console.log(body);
});

In order to run this program, you have to put the program in a project folder. Change the current directory to the project folder, then install the module with the command npm install request. (Note: the installation is also done once.) You’ll see that the command npm installs the module in a local folder called node_modules.

npm install request

The callback for request.get takes three parameters. The first is the error object. The second is an object of class http.IncomingMessage (online reference). It represents the HTTP response message. You can use it to check HTTP status code and headers. The last parameter is the message body of the HTTP response.

Options object pattern

The next example downloads an image from IPM website and saves it.

The JavaScript programming language does not support named parameters. Some APIs make use of a pattern caled options object pattern to pass named parameters to a function. For example, if you need to give more information about the HTTP request in addition to URL, you can group these information in an option object and pass it as the first parameter of reqeust.get(). Refer to online reference for all available options.

// p302.js
// - Download and save an image file from www.ipm.edu.mo

var fs = require('fs');
var request = require('request');

// options object pattern
// use a JS object to group named parameters
// encoding = null is required to get binary data
var options = {
  url: 'http://www.ipm.edu.mo/cntfiles/upload/images/common/campus/campusmap_btn_chi_un_img.jpg',
  encoding: null
};

request.get(options, (err, res, body) => {
  if (err) throw err;
  if (res.statusCode!==200) {
    console.log('HTTP status not ok. code = ', res.statusCode);
    return;
  }
  console.log('HTTP request is successful. Saving file...');
  fs.writeFile('campus.jpg', body, (err) => {
    if (err) throw err;
  });
});

Making POST request

In the next example, we want to download the class time table from the IPM web app at https://wapps.ipm.edu.mo/siweb/time_prog.asp. The web app uses HTTPS (instead of plain HTTP) and the POST method to send query to the server. The query data can be sent using the form property in the options object in request.post.

// p303.js
// - saves the response of a POST request to the file timetab.html

var request = require('request');
var fs = require('fs');

var form = {
  p_escl_cod: 5, /* ... */
  p_year_sem: '2015/2016-1',
  p_sp_year: 3,
  p_class_code: '31121'
};

var options = {
  url: 'https://wapps.ipm.edu.mo/siweb/time_prog.asp',
  form: form
};

request.post(options, (err, res, body) => {
  if (err) throw err;
  console.log('HTTP status: ' + res.statusCode);
  // write the HTML response body to an HTML file
  fs.writeFile('timetab.html', body, 'utf8', (err)=> {} );
});

Node app and package.json

As an Node application makes use of more NPM modules, it becomes difficult to install the modules manually with the command npm install module-name. Instead, you can describe the dependencies of a Node app in a JSON txt file called package.json.

You can create a package.json file for a Node app by running this command in the project folder.

npm init

A Node app contains 1 or more JavaScript file (*.js) together with modules and other assets (e.g. HTML files, images). All these file are put in a folder. A special file package.json describes the app. It defines the name and version, which identifies the app in the www.npmjs.com.

{
  "name": "comp312-examples",
  "description": "Examples of web client",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "private": true,
  "dependencies": {
    "request": "^2.75"
  }
}

The config file above indicates that our app depends on the ‘request’ module. It requires a version compatible with 2.75. For more detail about the version specification, refer to the online document for Semver.

After listing all the required modules for the current app in package.json, you can install all the dependencies with the command npm install. If later, you need to add a dependency (e.g. cheerio module), run the following command.

npm install cheerio --save

This command installs the latest version of specified module. In addition, it updates package.json and adds the module to the dependencies. Try the command and check the change in package.json.

item.title: 3-2 Select and change
item.description:
This lab shows how to select elements in the document tree using the $() jQuery function. You may then invoke methods on the resultant collection of elements.

Select by CSS selectors

This part uses the example file p302.html.

The jQuery library provides a powerful function to select elements from the document tree using CSS selectors. This function is sometimes known as the jQuery function $(). When provided with a CSS selectors, it returns a collection of HTML elements that are matched by the CSS selector.

Some examples:

  • $('#mesg') selects the element with id = mesg
  • $('.big') selects all elements that belong to class ‘big’
  • $('a') selects all elements of type a (i.e. all hyperlinks)
  • $('a[href^="http"]') selects all <a> elements with ‘href’ attribute that starts with “http”
  • $('img[alt="tiger"]') selects all <img> elements with ‘alt’ attribute that equals to “tiger”
  • $('img[src$="png"]') selects all <img> elements with ‘src’ attribute that ends with “png”
  • $('img[src*="tiger"]') selects all <img> elements with ‘src’ attribute that contains “tiger”

Change content and attributes

The result of $(selector) is a JavaScript object with many built-in methods. This is often called a jQuery collection. You typically use the methods to manipulate the HTML elements in a collection. The following retrieve or change the content of the selected elements.

  • $(selector).html() returns the HTML content of the first element in the collection
  • $(selector).html(value) sets the content of all the elements in the collection
  • $(selector).text() concatenates and returns the text content of all the elements in the collection
  • $(selector).text(value) sets the content of all the elements in the collection, and escapes the value with HTML entities, if required.

To access the attributes (e.g. src of <img>), use the following:

  • $(selector).attr(attrName) retrieves the attribute value of the named attribute of the first element in the collection
  • $(selector).attr(attrName, value) sets the attribute value of the named attribute of all elements in the collection

Exercise

Write a JavaScript program to display the Chinese birth sign for a given year birth. Start your work with p303.html. Refer to sample answer for a sample run.

To make the problem simpler, assume that the birth sign for a whole year is the same. For example, the birth sign for the year 2008 is rat. (In case you don’t know what birth sign is, please try this web site.)

Select by structure

When the HTML elements you want to select are embedded in other elements, you can use descendant selector, child selector and pseudo-class like :nth-child(n). Test the following collection in the example file p304.html.

  • $('table#marks td.fail') selects some table cells <td> inside a <table> with id = ‘marks’
  • $('ol > li:first-child') selects the first child of <ol>
  • $('ol li:first-child') selects all <li> that is itself a first child. The element must be inside <ol>

If you want to do your own processing on the elements in a jQuery collection, iterate the collection with a for .. of loop. Notice that each element retrieved by for .. of loop is a DOM element object. To use jQuery methods, convert the object into a jQuery collection with $(). Test the following in p304.html.

// this example adds 1 mark to exam of everybody!
// first, select all cells in the table body
var $cells = $('table#marks tbody td:nth-child(3)');
// for each HTML element in the jQuery collection ...
for (var c of $cells) {
  // use $() to make the DOM node into a jQuery collection
  // then, we can use .text() to read content
  var mark = $(c).text();
  mark = parseInt(mark);
  $(c).text(mark+1);
}

You can also use the $().each() method (see online reference).

// same effect as above, rewritten using $().each()
// first, select all cells in the table body
var $cells = $('table#marks tbody td:nth-child(3)');
// for each HTML element in the jQuery collection ...
$cells.each( (idx, c) => {
  // use $() to make the DOM node into a jQuery collection
  // then, we can use .text() to read content
  var mark = $(c).text();
  mark = parseInt(mark);
  $(c).text(mark+1);
});

Sometimes, you want to search for elements under a subtree of the DOM tree. You can use $().find(selector) to search for elements under the current matched set. For example, $('div#a').find('img') will return all <img> that are inside the <div> with id = a. Notice that $('div#a').find('img') gives the same jQuery collection as $('div#a img').

  • $().find(selector) selects descendants under each element in the jQuery collection. The descendants must match the selector, if specified.
  • $().children(selector) selects direct children under each element in the jQuery collection. The children must match the selector, if specified.
  • Similarly, you can find the parents $().parent() or siblings $().next(), $().prev(), $().siblings() of elements in a jQuery collection. See online reference for detail.

Consider this example. We want to calculate the final mark for the students in table#marks. Final mark = 40% x test mark + 60% x exam mark. Run this example in p304.html.

// for each row in the table body
for (var row of $('#marks tbody tr')) {
  // get the test mark from the 2nd cell
  var testmark = $(row).find('td:nth-child(2)').text();
  testmark = parseFloat(testmark);
  // get the exam mark from the 3rd cell
  var exammark = $(row).find('td:nth-child(3)').text();
  exammark = parseFloat(exammark);
  // calculate final mark and show it in the 4th cell
  var final = testmark * 0.4 + exammark * 0.6;
  $(row).find('td:nth-child(4)').text(Math.round(final));  
}

Select by position

You can select elements in a jQuery collection by position.

  • $(selector).eq(n) selects a single element at position n from the jQuery collection. n starts from 0
  • $(selector).length returns the number of elements
  • $(selector).slice(m,n) selects a range of elements

Exercise

  1. Add JavaScript code to p305.html to fill in the numbers in the multiplication table table#multitable when the user clicks the button below the table. You can refer to the output of the sample answer. However, before attempting to solve the questions, don’t read the source code of the answer.

  2. There is a tic tac toe game board in the file p306.html. Write a function show(stones) to set the game board according to the parameter, which is an array of 9 elements. An element of 0 corresponds to a circle, an element of 1 corresponds to a cross, and an element of 9 corresponds to an empty cell. Refer to the sample answer for a sample run.

Change CSS styles

There are two ways to change the CSS styles of elements. The first method is to add inline style with $().css(). Try the examples in p307.html.

  • $(selector).css(property, value) sets the CSS property to the specified value for all elements in the collection

When you need to set many CSS properties, a more organized method is to write the style change as style rules in CSS style sheet. Assign the style rules to a class.

.center {
  position: fixed; top: 30%; left: 30%;
  width: 300px !important; height: 300px !important;
  background-color: lightblue; border: 1px solid gray;
  border-radius: 30px; padding: 10px;
}

Then, in JavaScript, you can add the class to the element in runtime with $().addClass(). This approach also makes it easy to ‘undo’ the style change by removing the class from the element with $().removeClass(). Try the examples in p308.html.

  • $(selector).addClass(className) adds the specified class to the elements in the collection
  • $(selector).removeClass(className) removes the specified class from the elements in the collection

That example also defines a style rule for the table content and apply the rule to the table element in JavaScript. Read the source code for detail.

Exercise

Add JavaScript code to p309.html to show student’s name and mark. Complete the function show() according to the comment. You can refer to the output of the sample answer.

function show(name, mark) {
  // display the name in span#name
  // display the mark in span#mark
  // set the width of div#bar to the 2 * mark pixel
  // set its color to
  //    'red' if mark<50,
  //    'yellow' if it is between 50 and 80, and
  //    'green' if it is over 80.
  // your work ...
}

item.title: 2-2 Arrays and functions
item.description:
This lab goes through the basics of the JavaScript arrays and functions.

Array

An array keeps values in a sequence. Arrays can change size in run-time. You retrieve an element from an array by position. Use the operator [] to locate an element at the given index.

var a = [ 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 ];
console.log(`The second odd number is ${a[1]}.`);

var empty = [ ];  // empty array
empty[1] // undefined

The length property refers to the number of elements inside the array. A common method to iterate an array is to use for loop. You can read and write elements inside the loop using [ ].

var p = [ 2, 3, 5, 7, 11 ] ;  // small primes
for (var i=0; i<p.length; i++) {
  console.log(p[i]);
}

ES6 has a new control structure for of to iterate arrays and other iterable objects. You can use it to read the entries of an array one by one. This control structure is convenient when you only need to access the content of an array, but not the position.

var p = [ 2, 3, 5, 7, 11 ] ;  // small primes
for (var x of p) {
  console.log(x);
}

In case you need read-only access to the entries and their position, use the method .entries() of Array. The method is an iterable list of tuples [index, value].

var num = [ 'zero', 'um', 'dois', 'tres' ];
for (var [idx, s] of num.entries()) {
  console.log(`In Portuguese, ${s} means ${idx}.`)
}

Basic array methods

Arrays are objects in JavaScript and have some built-in methods. See online reference for a list of all methods. The following shows some common methods.

var A = [2,4];
A.push(6)  // A becomes [2,4,6]
A.pop(); // returns 6. A becomes [2,4]
A.unshift(0); // A becomes [0,2,4]
A.shift(); // returns 0

var b = [202,175,3,3];
var s = b.join('.'); // "202.175.3.3"

Arrays are useful to keep some values in order. The following example generates prime numbers less than 200. Is also demonstrates the usage of continue and loop label to force the next iteration. Please refer to online help for the detail usage of break and continue.

var p = [2, 3, 5, 7];
// give a label to the first for loop
loop1:
for (var k=9; k<200; k+=2) {
  loop2:
  for (var n of p) {
    // if k is divisible by a prime in p, continue onto k+2
    if (k % n == 0) continue loop1;
  }
  // after the above for loop, k is verified as prime
  p.push(k);
}
console.log(p);

Functions

There are two ways to define functions: the function keyword and arrow functions. This lab covers the first. We use a function to group some statements that can be reused.

// draw a right angle triangle of height n
function draw (n) {
  var out = "";
  for (var y=0; y<n; y++) {
    var s = "";
    for (var i=0; i<n-y-1; i++) s += ". ";
    for (var i=0; i<=y; i++) s += "* ";
    out += s+"\n";
  }
  console.log(out);
}

draw(5); // call the function to draw a triangle of height 5
draw(10); // draw again

Functions can return values to the calling code with return. The return statement also ends the execution of the functions immediately.

// this function compares the two parameters a and b, and returns the bigger one
function bigger (a,b) {
  if (a>b) {
    return a;
  } else {
    return b;
  }
}
console.log('The bigger one is ', bigger(2,3));

// another way to write
function bigger2 (a,b) {
  if (a>b) { return a; }
  return b;
}

// yet another way to write
function bigger3 (a,b) { return a>b ? a : b; }

The next example defines a function that finds the largest number in an array, assuming that the array has at least 1 element.

function max (num) {
  var x = num[0]; // assume the 0th element is the largest
  // compare x with each remaining element
  for (var k=1; k<num.length; k++) {
    if (num[k]>x) x = num[k];
  }
  return x;
}

max([2,3,5,8,7,1,4,6]); // return 8

A note on variable scope

In JavaScript, variables have function scope. That means that variables defined within a function are only visible inside the function. They are sometimes called local variables. Function parameters also work like local variables. A new copy of these variables is created when the function executes, and removed when no code has access to them anymore. For simple case like the above example, the local variables are removed when the function returns.

On the other hand, variables defined outside any functions are global variables, and are visible inside any functions. It is generally recommended to use global variables as little as possible.

In addition, you can define a function inside another function. Such nesting functions create nesting variable scopes.

Exercise

  1. Write a function sum(num) to calculate the sum of elements in an array num. Use the following code to test your function.

    var x = [1,2,3,4,5];
var ans = sum(x);
console.log('Correct? ', ans==15);

  2. Write a function odd(n) to generate an array of odd numbers less than or equal to n. Test your function with the following code.

    var a = odd(1);
console.log(a); // should print [1]
console.log(odd(9)); // should print [1,3,5,7,9]
console.log(sum(odd(10*2-1))); // should print 100

  3. Write a function search(num, n) to search for an number n in the array num. Return the position of the element if it is found. If it is not found, return -1. Test your function with the following code.

    var x = [6, 8, 3, -2];
console.log(search(x, 3)); // should print 2;
console.log(search(x, 1)); // should print -1;

The sample answers are available at p201.js, p202.js and p203.js respectively.

item.title: 5-3 Consuming a Web API
item.description:
In this lab, we’ll write client-side JavaScript to consume a Web API. We’ll use jQuery library to send GET and POST requests to the Web API.

Endpoints with GET method

There are two endpoints with GET method in our sample app.

method URL function
GET /getTodo List all tasks
GET /searchTodo Search tasks that are due before the given date.

In jQuery, the basic method to send Ajax call with GET method is $.get(url, callback). The callback runs if the browser receives a successful response (with status code 200 or other 2xx values). If the response message body has Content-type: application/json, jQuery will convert the message body into JavaScript.

$.get('/getTodo', (data) => {
  // data is JavaScript object derived from the JSON payload in response
  console.dir(data);
});

Adding input parameters to GET requests is also simple. Use a JavaScript object to encode key-value pairs. The following code sends a GET request to the URL /searchTodo?before=2016-10-10.

$.get('/searchTodo', { before: '2016-10-10' }, (data) => {
  // data is JavaScript object derived from the JSON payload in response
  console.dir(data);
});

Endpoints with POST method

One of the endpoint that use POST method in our sample app is /addTodo. The following code sends a POST request to the URL. The request body encodes the properties due, what, category in urlencoded format.

$.post('/addTodo',
   { due: '2016-12-13', what: 'comp312 final exam', category: 'study' },
   (data) => {
      // data is undefined because the endpoint returns 204 response with empty body
      console.dir(data);
   }
);

Below is a sample HTTP request that the above code sends.

POST /addTodo HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
Content-type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-length: 53

due=2016-12-12&what=comp312+final+exam&category=study

Refer to the source code of logic.js in the Ajax web app for how to use jQuery $.post() to consume the other endpoints in the web app.

Advanced topics

The following examples are some advanced example. They are included for your information only, and not used in our sample app.

Error handling

The callback as the second parameter of $.get() and $.post() only runs when the browser receives a successful response (usually with status code 200 or 204). To handle a response with error status code (e.g. 400, 404 and 500), you can register a callback with the method .fail().

$.post('/updateTodo',
  { xxid: 3, what: 'Woow!' },
  (data) => {
    console.log('success');  // data is undefined for 204 responses
  }
).fail( (jqXHR) => {
  console.log('error');
  console.log(jqXHR.status);
  console.log(jqXHR.statusText);
})

The first parameter of the callback is a jqXHR object, which provides various information about the Ajax call.

Sending JSON data in POST request

You have to use the low-level jQuery Ajax function $.ajax() to send JSON format data in POST requests. For example, to send the following HTTP request:

POST /addTodo HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
Content-type: application/json
Content-length: 80

{ "due": "2017-01-06", "what": "Makeup exam",
  "category": "study", "done": 0 }

… use the following code.

var query = { due: '2017-01-06', task: 'Makeup exam',
     category: 'study', done: 0 };
$.ajax('/addTodo', {
   type: 'POST',
   data: JSON.stringify(query),
   contentType: 'application/json',
   success: (data) => {
      // data is undefined for 204 response
   }
});

item.title: 4-3 Web app routing
item.description:
Express.js (official website) is a web framework to simplify development of Web applications. It supports:

  • Routing different request processing based on URL patterns
  • Middleware chainable processing of requests and responses
  • Template generate HTML output from variables

This lab covers how to define routes to capture HTTP requests for a web app / service endpoints. In addition, we’ll discuss how to generate simple HTTP responses.

Routes

This example shows the basic structure of an Express app.

var express = require('express');
// create an Express application, which will handle HTTP requests
var app = express();

// a route in the app, which handles GET request for the path '/'
app.get('/', (req, res) => {
  res.send('hello world');
});

// more routes ...

// start listening at TCP port 3000
app.listen(3000);

When a web app receives an HTTP request, it has to decide how to handle the request, and return the result as an HTTP response. Such decision usually depends on the HTTP method (either GET or POST in most cases) and the path in the URL (e.g. “/about.html”). The combination of HTTP method and the URL path is usually referred to as an endpoint of the web app or web service.

In an Express app, we define a route to describe how to process HTTP requests at an endpoint. The general syntax is app.get(path, callback) and app.post(path, callback). The callback can take 2 or more parameters. Often, we only use the first two parameters called req and res: req refers to the incoming HTTP request, and res is an object that is used to build the HTTP response. The following is a route for GET request at URL ‘/about.html’. The route returns a text response.

// app is an Express app

app.get('/about.html', (req, res) => {
  // When the Express app receives a GET request
  // for the path '/about.html', it returns a text response
  res.send('This is a simple example of route')
});

Some web apps include parameters in the URL path. For example, the URL https://www.google.com/maps/place/Macao+Polytechnic+Institute/ refers to the place ‘Macao Polytechnic Institute’ in the Google Maps web app. You can easily extract these parameters in Express routes.

Consider the sample code below, which shows a web app to check lecture hours. When the app receives a GET request for the path ‘/lecture/comp312’, it returns a response of its lecture hours. The parameters are available in the object req.params. (The full source is app1.js).

// retrieve the lecture time
app.get('/lecture/:code', (req, res) => {
  // in a real app, we'd query a database ...
  if (req.params.code=='comp312') {
    res.send('Tue, Thu: 10:00-11:30am')
  } else if (req.params.code=='comp311') {
    // ...
  }
})

The above only describes the basics of routing in Express. Refer to the online guide for more possibilities.

The order of routes is significant! An Express app checks the routes in the order they are defined. When a route matches the HTTP methods and URL path, the Express app executes its callback function to handle the request. The callback usually returns an HTTP response with res.send() or similar methods. When a response is returned, the Express app will stop checking the remaining routes.

app.get('/lecture/comp312', (req, res) => {
  // special response for comp312
  res.send('...');
});

// retrieve the lecture time
app.get('/lecture/:code', (req, res) => {
  // search database, return a response
  res.send('...');
});

app.get('/lecture/comp113', (req, res) => {
  // special response for comp113. But sorry, this route never runs!
  res.send('...');
});

Making responses

You can use the res object in the route callback to build a response. (online reference) The res object has several common methods:

  • res.send(body) sends a response with the specified body. The body is usually a string, but it can also be JavaScript objects or others. The method determines the suitable MIME type.
  • res.sendFile(path) returns a file as response.
  • res.status(code) sets the HTTP response code. This function is chainable.
  • res.redirect(path) redirects to the given URL.

Check the source code of app2.js for demonstration of how to build responses with these methods.

item.title: 3-3 Creating new content
item.description:
This lab covers how to create new content into the document tree using $() jQuery functions and methods.

Create new HTML content

You can create new HTML content by passing HTML code to the jQuery function $(htmlCode). The newly created elements are detached from the current document tree, and not displayed. To show the content, you have to attach the elements to the document tree. Run the following code in p311.html.

var p = $('<p>A new paragraph <em>created</em> by jQuery</p>');
dir(p);
// append to the document body to show this element
$('body').append(p);
// now you can see it

When you supply HTML code to jQuery function, it returns a jQuery collection, just like the collection returned when you supply a CSS selector. Therefore, you can use the jQuery methods like $().html() or $().attr() to configure the newly created elements.

var img = $('<img>').attr('src', 'ani/dragon.png');
$('body').append(img);

var link = $('<a>').html('Macao Poly').attr('href', 'http://www.ipm.edu.mo');
// this is the same as $('<a href="http://www.ipm.edu.mo">Macao Poly</a>');
$('body').append(link);

By the way, you can detach an element from the document tree with $().detach() or $().remove, and reinsert it later. To remove all content inside an element, use $(selector).empty().

// move all images to the end of the document
var img = $('img').detach();
$('body').append(img);

// make the document body empty
$('body').empty();

Insert content to document tree

There are several methods you can use to insert new / existing content into the current document tree.

  • $().append(content) - adds the content at the end of each element in the collection
  • $().prepend(content) - adds the content at the start of each element in the collection
  • $().after(content) - adds the content after each element in the collection
  • $().before(content) - adds the content before each element in the collection

If the source content is already attached to the current document, the content is removed first, and then attached at the target location. If you want to keep the source content at the original position, clone the source content before inserting with $().clone().

Now, go through the examples in p312.html.

The four insertion methods have a counterpart version that reverse the order of source and target. ($().appendTo(), $().prependTo(), $().insertBefore() and $().insertAfter()) They are useful if you want to chain other methods on the source. See online reference or more detail.

$('#rooster').after($('#tiger'))
// is the same as ...
$('#tiger').insertAfter($('#rooster'))

The following creates new rows and inserts into the table. See the demo p313.html

var $t = $('table tbody');
// clear the table body
$t.empty();
for (var k=16; k<32; k++) {
  // create a new row
  var $r = $('<tr>');
  // and append three cells to the row
  $('<td>').html(k).appendTo($r);
  $('<td>').html(k.toString(2)).appendTo($r);
  $('<td>').html(k.toString(16)).appendTo($r);
  // append the row to the table body
  $t.append($r);
}

Exercise

In this exercise, you have to populate an HTML table with JSON data in p314.html. Refer to the sample answer for the required output format.
